recommended_requirements: OS: Windows 8/10 (64-bit OS required) Processor: Intel i7 920 @ 2.7 GHz, AMD Phenom II 945 @ 3.0 GHz Memory: 8 GB RAM Graphics: NVIDIA GTX 660, Radeon R9-270 DirectX: Version 11 Storage: 3 GB available space Sound Card: 100% DirectX 9.0c compatible sound card

reviews.review_text: I see people complaining how short this game is. Personally, I'd rather play 3-5 hours of perfection than 50+ of repetitive, unoriginal crap.   The atmosphere and design are like nothing I've ever seen in a platform styled game. To be honest, you're doing INSIDE a disservice by considering it a platformer. The puzzles are challenging, yet not frustrating, and the ending leaves you with chills. TIP: (minor spoiler)   Make sure you collect all of the orbs for the secret ending.    This game is a genuine masterpiece.

INSIDE was a bit more atmospheric, interesting and deeper than LIMBO. but alot shorter. The puzzles were easier.. I loved everything about it, besides it being so short for 20 dollars. It was very fun and I highly recommend it. I have a feeling anything Playdead comes out with will be enjoyable.

Run, kid, run.   And stumble, fall, get back on your feet and run some more. Then, jump, swim, crawl.  Hide.  They're after you, all of them.  They won't let you go.  I can hear you breathe, your heart is pounding.  Scared and brave, you keep going, keep running. Where are you taking me, kid? Where am I taking you?  Oh, how many dark places, such dangers we have encountered. Yet you keep running, they won't stop you, I promise. I will help you.  Because that's what you want me to do, right?    °°° Sometimes the word 'game' doesn't fit well. If something wraps you in its world, atmosphere and doesn't let you go, not even when the whole thing is done, if you feel you're not the same anymore once it's finished, 'game' can't be the right word. Yet, INSIDE couldn't be more classic in its gameplay: a 2D side-scrolling platformer without levels, with puzzles to be solved in order to progress, jumps to take, dangers to avoid etc. Yet again, it's immersive in such a powerful way that it makes you forget that those are mere gameplay mechanisms: you are in the story, so each action you perform is part of that.  The music, or better, the  lack of  it most of the time, just the ambient sounds from a deserted landscape, the kid's hearbeat sometimes, so that when music suddenly starts, it leaves you speechless (there's a specific moment when this happens underwater, whose beauty and feeling of agoraphobia I won't easily forget). And the dim light most of the time. So that each time you run into sunshine, you want the kid to bask in it... and stop for a little, because you have no idea when - and if - he'll feel that sunshine again.  Overall, its bleak atmosphere engulfs you in ways that I'm finding hard to explain. As I previously said, INSIDE stays with you long after everything is done, leaving you with countless questions and a mix of inexplicable feelings.
This game has amazing ideas with puzzles. I hope to win best game this year 2016. Recommended to anyone like challenge

When's the last time a game actually made you stop and say wow? We play so many we become numb to them. People complain this game is too short, but I'd rather have 4 hours of this than 50 hours of meh. Great puzzles and interaction, amazing art direction / sound design and also shows what the Unity engine can do in the right hands. Just buy it!

No game is perfect, neither in general amongst video games nor within its own genre. Of all the games I've ever played, INSIDE may very well be the closest thing to perfect - in all aspects - in both regards. It warrants every single word of praise that exists for it. I cannot recommend it highly enough.
Everyone is losing their minds about pokemon go and i am here playing this insanely good game called INSIDE...
A dark, gloomy and artistic game with great art direction and craftsmanship. I saw and played things I had never seen or experienced before in a game. I highly recomend it.
One of the most beautiful and meaningful experience I've ever played. The soundtrack and sound design is up there with the best. 10/10.
Cannot recommend enough. Simple gameplay with some tricky puzzles but its all about the story. Still don't know exactly which I think is the point. Brill!
Detailed review   by Ashes    Introduction
There are few games that uses so little to create a beautiful world and a excellent story. It is short but I think this is one of the best games I have ever played 10/10
Like LIMBO but creepier

Holy Cow! What a game! It took me completely by surprise. I knew it was from the creators of Limbo but since I wasn't that big of a fan of Limbo to begin with, I didn't go into INSIDE with the highest of expectations, but boy oh boy was I wrong. There are no negatives, so I'm just gonna list the positives, and trust me, there are many:  - I'm not a 'puzzle guy' but these puzzles were incredible: They were surprisingly fun, challenging. inventive and varied. - The 'graphics' and atmosphere in this game are some of the best I've ever seen in an indie game. The game has a distinct 'cell shaded' look to it and it almost plays exactly like a top notch animation. It's all extremely fluid, which brings me to my next point... - The physics in this game are absolutely incredible... Towards the end (NO SPOILERS), my jaw dropped to the floor when certain things started happening. It's just stunning stuff. - The sound design and the Soundtrack were also beautifully done and they fit the game perfectly. - The 'plot', if you could call it that, is something Sci-Fi fans will love, especially if you're into movies like Akira, Blade Runner, John Carpenter's The Thing and David Lynch's Eraserhead. - Finally, I'd like to mention the controls and how fluid and responsive they are. It feels like the game's playing itself. And it works perfectly with my Dualshock 4 (Plug and Play basically).  This is game is perfect. No two ways around it. It looks and sounds great, it plays even better and it has some of the best atmosphere you'll ever find in a game, indie or otherwise. This game is a MUST play, in my opinion.

I really liked Limbo. I loved the visual style and atmosphere of the game, I loved the soundtrack, and I loved the way that there wasn't any concession made to conventional cinematographic storytelling techniques in the game - because those things weren't relevant to the experience of playing the game. And yes, there were a number of points in the game where you would be 'ambushed' - but for enough of the game, it was possible to try and guess what would happen next and do something to try and avoid that particular grisly death.  Inside is basically Limbo again, but unbalanced. The gameplay and presentation technique will be very familiar if you've played Limbo. The visual style is striking - lots of shadow and muted palates infrequently broken up by short sharp shocks of bright colour and light. Although I have to say that, for me, the decision to render the environments in 3D despite the game being a resolutely 2D platformer didn't make sense - especially not with a lot of the level design, which features numerous instances of puzzles which are only puzzles because you can't get the protagonist to move 2 steps into the background or foreground to grab an object there or use an alternative route there.  As with Limbo, the soundtrack and overall use of sound is once again great. It's haunting, atmospheric and evocative, doing a lot of work to sell the environment of the game.  But the gameplay...well, the gameplay is the same as it was in Limbo, but with more game stretched out over fewer puzzles or ideas, and less of them particularly inventive - more often than not the puzzles aren't clever, or particularly difficult to work out, they just involve finicky timing. Without enough interesting variation to hold your attention.  I really want to like Inside. But it's a game with magnificent sound and a fascinatingly weird world that I want to explore, in which movement is limited to fixed paths, narrative is non-existent and gameplay is pedestrian.   If you liked Limbo and want a similar experience, you'll find something like that here. But I would wait until it was on sale.

INSIDE is a game that you have never experienced before and will never experience again. It is a story. It is a beauty and a confusion. And there is no other way to describe it. Follow your faceles little boy in a world that you will never truly comprehend and never truly believe. Evade dogs and masked people and creatures living deep in the water. Scurry around trying to solve puzzles and feeling stupid when you figure it out.  The price may seem too much, but if you just stop and listen and watch what happens in the tiniest of moments. Listen to sounds of the faceless boy, watch his movements. This game is beautifully polished. From the background to the smallest interactions of characters. So if you feel like taking on an interesting adventure for a few interesting hours, I highly recommend this game.  Good luck.

Creepy, weird, fun, brain puzzles, short. Overall a great game, would definitely recommend it. Try to go in as spoiler free as possible or at least don't spoil the ending for yourself.    Have fun!   Also, if you liked LIMBO.. you will love this game. ;)

Finished it in around 3 hours. Easily worth the price of admission, i enjoyed it more than any recent theater movie which comes in at the same price tag. As expected, there is nothing to the end here, though i didnt expect to be surprised, but was, at least twice, during it. ;)  Its a visual (joy)ride. A brilliant one.  About Meat.

Inside is a beautiful, thought provoking puzzle based platform game. But it's actually much more than that. If you've ever played Another World, Brothers: a tale of two sons or Limbo - this game shares the same interesting, engaging story-driven gameplay that compells you to empathise with its characters. I wanted to play it because I desperately wanted to succeed, not for myself, but for the main character. I wanted answers, I wanted justice, I wanted freedom.   Inside will be etched into my mind for years to come. 10/10.
the game is really great what are you waiting for ... get it now

More neutral than anything, it's not a bad game, but it seems like a lesser Limbo. It looks pretty sure, but that's one of the very few pros for this game compared to Limbo.  Personally, I think it's overpriced for what it delivers, definitely pick it up in the sale since it has a really interesting twist at the end and it gives you enough bait to piece together a story that you think would make sense, but at the same time has some 'plot holes'. Also some of the puzzles are fairly repetitive/'Eh', which is a shame.  If it was around the same price as Limbo, deffo worth a buy, but at £14.99, 3 hours doesn't exactly cut it for me.
Graphics are just nice. And the background music too.
I ordered me some wings to enjoy while I play this and when I finished the game , at the very end I realized...I forgot to eat the wings. MASTERPIECE!!! playdead delivers once again!

INSIDE is another game, made by Playdead, well known for LIMBO.  If you've played LIMBO, I can certainly say that this game will not disappoint. In case you're unfortunate enough to not have played it, let me sum up what you can expect out of INSIDE.  INSIDE is a 2D-like platformer, with 3D to support it, and you play as a young boy, risking life and limb, traversing this well crafted world. You'll be solving several platforming puzzles, as you travel through the game, and have to make sure any hazards won't kill you. Compared to LIMBO, there's not too many hazards to deal with, but it makes the game feel more exploration based, and you'll certainly feel dread as you explore the game. The deaths are just as nasty as in LIMBO, but describing them, would spoil the surprise. ;)  Like LIMBO, the game has hidden collectibles, is rather linear, rather simplestic (which is a good thing), and has an amazing ambient soundtrack to set the mood (it was composed with a skull!), as you explore and complete puzzles. There's nothing better than having the game reward your smarts, for finding a solution to a hazardous puzzle, than ambient music that's screaming 'well done, you didn't die!'.  Long story short: INSIDE is a highly recommendable puzzle platformer that is so aesthetically pleasing, yet still highly enjoyable game.
Dunno what the hell happened, but enjoyed every second of it :D
Absolutely fantastic puzzle and level design, which is difficult but not frustrating. Incredible tonal shifts and musical cues when you reach critical points in the story. Definitely worth the $20.

You like LIMBO? This is 10000% for you  Things i don't like DOGS Echo-sound-bullet that you cannot see. WATER-TYPE GHOST from Amnesia, this time you can see it x_x  9/10, best game ever No need to be on sale, the price itself is worth it

It was way darker than it seemed at my first glance.   The atmosphere of this game is incredible. It's because of the visuals, the sounds and the soundtrack - and how they are incorporated into eachother and work together.  The story of the game is a mystery, but it is clear that there is a red herring throughout the game. There is a hidden message. Figuring it out is not easy. You wouldn't believe some of the theories and discussions floating online.   I think Inside is perfect, and wouldn't change a single thing about it. I played the game slowly, walking instead of running. I think that is the best way of experiencing it, both when it comes to the atmosphere, and noticing the surroundings and its hidden secrets and clues to what the game really is about.

Just incredible. I just finished it and I much say I am speechless. Just speechless.   Worth the money just to experience the journey it puts you on. The amount of WTF moments put you on the edge of your seat and just when you thought it could not get any crazier it does just that.   all i can really say is Holy S*%t......

LIMBO 1.25. INSIDE for me is LIMBO, slightly upgraded in certain areas and downgraded in others.   What's good: + gorgeous 2,5d graphics (3d backgrounds, 2d 'main' plane that you use to move) + fantastic particle effects and physics effects + dark atmosphere enhanced by intense color palette + few interesting puzzles and 'plot twists'  What's bad: - imo puzzles are less interesting than LIMBO ones and there's much less of them overall - a lot of running around (LIMBO had this too, but it was less frustrating) - annoying underwater puzzles - 3 hours of gameplay for 20$/€  So yea, it's like slightly more frustrating (to navigate) LIMBO with different (arguably better) graphics and less puzzles. Not bad overall.
Don't even want to come close to spoiling anything so I'll just say the art direction, sound, and pacing in this game are sublime. Spend an evening to play straight through and you won't regret it.
very chalanging, despite its short gameplay. but the story is much deeper, the atmosphere is very intense.
Great extension of everything that made Limbo an awesome game. Creepy and ambient and fun as hell. 10/10 would recommend.

This game is gorgeous. Right from the start, even with the relatively slow pace of the game, it grabs you and refuses to let go. Impressively, with no language either written or spoken, they manage to wrest your empathy and attention throughout and build an incredibly engaging story and world. The backgrounds and animation are superb, and the atmosphere soul achingly engaging. The puzzles start light and gradually start to surprise you with their complexity and originality. The characters and creatures you encounter in the game are ruthless and brutal and all work together to create an oppressed and disparaging world that you never want to leave.  A puzzle platformer at the height of it's game. Must have.
inside uses a very simple format to create some tense, atmospheric, dreadful, and cool moments.  I really recommend it.
That certainly was... insane.
AMAZING GAME!!! some of the most intense stuff I've played in a long time. Game is short but its never a bore 10/10
This game isn't really that scary, it's more atmospheric and creepy. I can't imagine why you wouldn't like it. Perfect length and very conceptual. Will definitely be playing again.

I was uncomfortable from start to finish. 11/10

When Inside was first introduced I couldn't wait for it to come out. After playing Limbo, I thought Inside was going to be awesome. Well for me, when Inside first started, it was awesome. But as I started getting through the game I became disappointed. The challenges did not seem as difficult as Limbo as the storyline just didn't seem right. To me it seemed to extream/odd of a storyline.  The Positive of the game, I really like the graphics/art of the game. I can give the artists a 2 thumbs up for the art work.
If you loved limbo then this is just as amazing. Short, sweet and simplistic. 9/10

This is one of the greatest games I have ever played. Its only flaw is I wish it were longer. Thats what she said. However it certainly satisfies in other ways. The graphics are both simple yet gorgeous. The attention to detail in regard to the level design and the way the NPC's react to you is a masters class in how do design a game. The deaths can be brutal and horrifying. The puzzles are clever but not maddening. Why are you not playing this game?
Beautiful, fun, and pricy for it's length.
It's so wrong to call this a game.  It's an experience. And it's just mind-blowing.  Play it. Just play it. Now.
There actually aren't words for the stylised perfection that this game is. 10/10 am playing again.  If you're looking for a sign, this is it. Good luck
Holy....  It's a fascinating game. Worth the money. I recommend to everyone!

Really atmospheric and really fun and creative puzzles. The deaths are surprising in a good way and add to the experience. Really recommend it especially now that they've fixed a bug that had problems with light and made some puzzles difficult
Simply the best game I've played in this genre.

After playing LIMBO, I was really upset that it had to end and that I finished it, wishing there was a lot more to it. It was my favorite Indie game EVER, until I played INSIDE. INSIDE is seriously a phenomenal step from LIMBO, and now holds the title has my most loved indie game. I also looked at a few things involving the soundtrack (I'm a musician myself) because I really enjoy working with audio software and keyboard/ambient pads. These guys took an ACTUAL HUMAN SKULL, attached a microphone and placed it inside of the skull, played a pre made keyboard track, and the reverberations inside of the skull from the pads make this soundtrack THE COOLEST soundtrack to a game I have ever heard. When I found that out, I imediately had mad respect for Playdead. LIMBO was fantastic, INSIDE was ASTOUNDING, and I simply can't even wait to see what Playdead brings to the table next.
The perfect sequal to LIMBO. 10/10 for me.
Very intriguing and atmospheric game
Absolutely flawless. 10/10
it is a wonderful game ,and the sight is cool but less difficult,sometimes the music can scare my ♥♥♥♥ out ,lol

Postive: - The dark atmospher is some of the best you will find in a video game - You want to play to the end of the game to see what this weird story is all about - Controls are very responsive  - The game is well optimized and can run on low end systems with ease  Negative: - The game is VERY short. It's a 3-4 hours game. - Not much replay value. But that depends on the player of course  Verdict:  INSIDE is not a bad game. It's very good at what it aims to do and that it's to create a dark atmospher for the gameplay. I had fun playing the game to the end and I am gald I did . But for me, 20 euros is just a to high for a game with so little replay value and puzzles that are VERY easy to solve.  Get the game on sale and play it in a DARK room and enjoy it for what it is :)
Splendid game - had a blast playing it. A bit short but the atmosphere makes up for it. Some nice visual surprises and a superb soundtrack. Could be cheaper.  8.5 Freshies out of 10

Its got beauty, its got brains, its got fun. Buy it, dont be dumb. A lot of people are complaining it costs too much at the moment - I disagree. If youre low on funds you probably shouldnt be looking at buying games right now. Common sense nonwithstanding the game, i think, is priced well inview of the amount of polish and fun the game provides. INSIDE is spooky, scary in places, and fun. People also seem to whinge about the story, certain events, locations, and unexplained items. Why? Do you need your hand held? Picture this: this is a game which is trying to achieve a sense of suspension of reality. We play games for this. Perhaps youre NOT an omniscient protagonist and you dont have all the answers. Pretty scary to find yourself seemingly breaking out of a vast, strange facility and on the run from people who seem to want you dead for a reason you have no idea of.  Personally I love games that dont hold your hand. Youre totally in the dark. And its atmospheric. Perfectly done.

'Limbo, but better'  The game looks amazing.  The puzzles are challenging enough to be rewarding but achievable to keep the flow of the game.   The core of the game is in essence a simple platformer, but it is the attention to detail that take a simple game and creates a true gem.  While £15 for a game you can complete in 2 - 3 hours is expensive, in my opinion it is worth the money for the exceptional atmosphere that Playdead have created,
An intriguing mellow 2D platformer. Great retro/futuristic, 50's sci-Fi feel and a very clean graphical styling to this game. Highly Recommended.

Inside is one of the best video game experiences I have ever had. As far as I am concerned, it is absolutely flawless.  I enjoyed Play Dead's previous title Limbo, however in my mind it wasn't as perfected. It was incredibly atmospheric and beautiful, but I felt the pacing was a bit too long as well as repetetive in parts. Don't get me wrong, I absolutely adore Limbo and it really kickstarted the 'indie' gaming movement and is a classic. Anyways, back to Inside. Actually, before I say anything about Inside I need to talk about another short 20ish dollar title which many people really enjoyed.   Firewatch. So I was MASSIVELY disappointed with that game. I am all for games that rely on imagination and the preconceptions of the player, HOWEVER the FW ending to me felt unbelievably forced leaving virtually no room for interpretation at the end. See, Inside doesn't have a perfect ending with a bow wrapped around it. It leaves the story and the impact it has on the player, well, up to the player! This is why I absolutely adored it. There are already a RIDICULOUS amount of interpretations from the game that have popped up online. As others have suggested I HIGHLY recommend every player finds the alternate ending as well, it adds some very interesting elements.   Aesthetically the game is stunning, with this bleak artstyle that is hauntingly beautiful. The animation is some of the smoothest I have ever seen and the particle effects are outstanding. The visuals always conjure up feelings of unease and can at times be quite disturbing. I am at a time in my life where I work and go to college and don't have alot of time (or frankly the will power) to get immersed in a massive game. That being said, I completed this game twice in one sitting. I fell in love.   The gameplay I feel is where this game ticked all the right boxes for me. This is very much a visual narrative, similar to Limbo. However, the puzzles are much easier and don't require a whole lot of trial and error. I believe this was very much intentional because of the length of Limbo. I was also amazed at the pacing of the title. It clocks in at around 3 hours but it felt like 30 minutes. Along the way there are certain simple mechanics that are introduced. If this were any other game made by another studio the developers would have abused said mechanic to 'pad' the game. Each new 'shtick' is introduced once and used, only once. This was utterly refreshing to me.  What will make or break this game for you is what you desire out of a title. Do you want a solid story with a satisfying conclusion? If so, I suggest you wait for a sale as you will be disappointed. However, if you want something truly unique and thought provoking I highly recommend you give Inside a shot. Whatever you do, DO NOT watch any videos or read anything about it. The story goes some truly fantastic ways that I do not believe should be spoiled for anyone.

What seems to at first to be nothing more than a fanservice filled loveletter to LIMBO, INSIDE quickly diverges from its campy Iron Giant-eque beginning into an eerie Orwellian world filled with plenty of scares and tense moments. Gameplay wise, I feel the puzzles are lacking compared to Limbo overall, such as some puzzles being a touchy pain to deal with (ie. hiding underneath a pipe to avoid a hostile light fixture). However, most of the puzzles were enjoyable, just a tad on the easy side along with the occassional irritating task. The game did nail the atmosphere down with the gloomy subdued color pallete and the lonely urban backgrounds. Overall I believe this game does warrant a purchase, although if you don't care for backgrounds and tone I'd suggest waiting for a sale.

The big thing that people keep bringing up is that it takes about 3 hours to complete. While this is true, and as the game stands at $19.99, Those 3 hours were the most mind boggling and intense 3 hours I've ever experienced. Most $60 triple A titles that say it takes 8 hours or more to complete their game usually mean about 3 hours of actual gameplay and 5 hours of cutscenes and/or aimless wandering. I would argue that the money you spend on this game is money well spent, its very reasonably priced for what it delivers. I've recently completed the game and it left me speechless, and i want to go back and find everything I missed, this means another 3+ hours more of gameplay (sure its the same story over again, but the point is I was left wanting to experience it again.) If you're on a low game budget, I would argue that this is the game you would want to spend your money on. The odd sense of urgency throughout the entire game kept me playing all the way to the end. Even though not a single word was uttered throughout the entire game, the game had more story than most movies these days and it still leaves me pondering what actually happened.

Inside is a gem of a game. An unexpected pleasure to play. While I loved Limbo from the same developer, Playdead, it felt a little lacking in content and the journey finished sooner than anticipated. Inside isn't that much longer either but for the few hours it lasts, it's a worthwhile trip down mystery lane. The simple clean visuals complement the detailed atmosphere, the rich sound effects and the intense situations. The only reason I'm giving this a 9/10 is the lack of more things to do and more mechanics. You see, the more you play this game, the less you want it to end and the more mechanics you wish for - slow progression, basic weapons or clever tricks to defend your frail self etc. But as it stands, this game is worth EVERY rupee spent, And it is best played in bursts, to stretch the experience out. DON'T RUSH IT. TAKE IT SLOW. ABSORB IT ALL. This isn't meant to be just entertainment. This is meant to be an EXPERIENCE. Few games remain as memorable to me but this one will go down on my all time favorites list. Great Job Playdead!!. Eager to see what you Indie guys can create as your next game - maybe even a full budget big game eh?? :P  Can't wait for this to come to PS Vita as well. Eventually :)

Once in a while a game comes along which strips free from the commonplace, carving its own style, substance and ideas. It is art in its purest form. No tropes, guidelines, or recycled content just a game that can stand on it's own and hold up it's hand shouting 'Look at me!' Inside is one of these rare games.  The game feels like a vignette or collage of ideologies, stories and themes. There is no dialogue, no menus, or on screen prompts, just a pure unadulterated experience from start to finish. Like all great pieces it surpasses genre. Horror, sci-fi, drama. And most of all it carries some very potent themes of existentialism, with a very orwellian style of atmosphere.  It is so meticulously crafted that you start to think the developers scrutinizingly made it pixel by pixel. Animation is fluid and creative, and sound design among the best I've heard in decades. Framing and compositional techniques are brought to the forefront. The way the camera moves in 2.5d space is very satisfying and the developers clearly guide your eye to where you want to be looking, be it through use of color or pulling in the camera. The palette of colors changes throughout the game seemingly to reflect certain feeling or moods, beginning with a very monochromatic look and towards the end breathing some life into the frame with splashes of orange and blue.  This is quite frankly a masterclass in developing games and for me is the best game I've played this decade. If you're on the fence, just do yourself a favor and buy it.
Very well done. Just holy crap that ending. 10/10

First of all, sorry about my English. It isn't my native language, but I tried my best to wrote a good and understandable review.   Intro:   PlayDead's Limbo is one of the best videogames I've ever played (I completed nearly 600 games to this day). It was the game that showed to me (and to lot of others aswell) how good an independent and smaller game can be. Limbo had an amazing atmoshpere with an intelligent, layered, visual story-telling with a bit of symbolism, and had awesome puzzle and platforming sections... and a touching, cathartic ending.  6 years after the release of the mentoined cult classic, PlayDead's new game finally arrived. Inside builds upon the foundation that made Limbo great, so there's a lot of similarities between the two games, but at the same time, they are completely different from each other.   Story:   While Limbo was a much more personal experience, Inside's story is more about the possible future's society, the importance of our consciousness, and it's a critics about today's brainwashed people too in a very interesting way - at least in my interpretation. If you seen The Matrix, Dark City, Abre los Ojos, Equilibrium, or any similar movies, you must be understand a little bit more what I'm talking about. This is one of the many aspects that make this game great: there's a lot of room for different interpretations about it's story.   Art Design / Visual Style:   The other important difference between the two games is the visual style. While both games have a very distinct art design, Inside has much more details, and a little bit more colors too compared to Limbo's black and white dominated landscape. But maybe the most important change in terms of the visuals is the 2,5D nature of Inside. This thing alone makes the game's world much more alive - at least for me. There's a lot more things happening in the background, and it usually affects the gameplay too in an interesting way.   Gameplay:   Well, if I mentoined gameplay, I want to talk about that too. It's very fun and addictive, but it's definitely more straightforward this time, at least I didn't really stuck anywhere in the game. The puzzles - most of the time - were pretty easy to solve. On the other hand, it was a lot longer than Limbo, it took me 4 hours to finish it. (By the way, it hasn't got any achievements -maybe because the developers wanted you to play the game for the game, so you don't need to play attention to these distractions... they can break the immersion and the general focus sometimes.) My bad, it actually has achievements.   Atmoshpere:   The atmoshpere is top-notch, and not just because the excellent visual design. Very few artists can use silence in an effective way (few honorable mentions: Stanley Kubrick: various movies, Christopher Nolan: Interstellar - sorry, I'm a movie-freak too), but PlayDead can - they already proved it with Limbo, and they proved it again with Inside. There are very few sounds, or music through the game. But when they are playing, they are very, very effective.   Verdict:   If it wasn't obvious enough, it's a masterpiece. If you admit that gaming is an art form, and if you aren't a guy with an IQ of 70 or less, who socialized on commercial trash, like CTRL+C/CTRL+V repetitive open-world games, borefest grind-shooters, dumb Hollywood movies (made by the lowest common denominator kept in mind), or 'music' loved by the mass - so in other words, if you are an intelligent human being, you are going to love this.   A final advice:   I think in order to really appreciate Inside, after you completed it, days need to past, and you need to think about it, what was this amazing journey is all about. Don't worry, this game makes you think anyway. Day by day, slowly you can realize the meaning of the story, and at the same time you can slowly understand the important messages and symbolism too.

Hands down my GOTY so far for 2016!  This was one of THE MOST incredible experiences I've ever had from a video game. I was left utterly speechless when the game finished.  Everything is so polished and well done, kudos to the devs for another (major step up from even the well received, Limbo) fantastic title. The visuals are beautiful and dark, the atmosphere is just incredible, the small details, the audio, the fluidity of the controls. Everything about this game had me completely engrossed.  Recommend trying to finish it in one playthrough, but you'll be so hooked that you wouldn't think of doing otherwise. It's short, but I think it's the perfect length for this kind of narrative.  Thank you, Playdead. I'm actually overwhelmed at how amazing that experience was.
Play INSIDE. It's a beautiful and satisfying platformer.
Was a very imersive game. I had no idea that the environment would seem that massive. It's an awesome experience.

If you think a 2 hour game justifies the 15 pound price point then sure its the best game ever. It improves upon almost every aspect besides the short length and puzzles when compared to Limbo. Atmosphere alone warrants a playthrough.   I'd say its great, if you can grab it at half its price during sale.

That was... Strange, fascinatingly strange.  Playdead nailed the atmospheric puzzle-platformer again. Yeah, this game feels like it hits the beats a little too similarly to LIMBO at times, but all-around feels more refined and a bit more coherent to the story it's telling. The mechanics and gimmicks are different from LIMBO too, I think it's just a matter that Playdead's filling a niche that they're good at and there's nothing wrong with that if they do it well, and damn do they ever! One thing I love is that while LIMBO felt like it really frontloaded its best parts, INSIDE cushions the big moments throughout, so I never felt too dragged through an excess of puzzle sections. Not much really outstays its welcome to any unreasonable extent.  If you're a fan of Interplay's old classics, stuff like Heart of Darkness or like the Oddworld games, or if you just played LIMBO and liked it well enough, you may want to check this out. Only detractions I've heard about or experienced are length and price. Yes, it's under 3 hours according to my Steam time for a solid playthrough, but really it didn't feel like that to me, I got lost in its world and lost track of time, and a good game will do that to you, I kept wondering how many hours passed, I was seriously surprised when I saw my time played.  Will I be playing it again? Maybe not soon, but LIMBO brought me back in with its alternatingly sinister and tranquil world, as well as memorable moments, and I think INSIDE will do the same. If anything, wait for a sale, but I really do think it's worth playing,
Excellent both in act, sound and scene. I strongly recommend.

I'm torn about this game. At the end of the day I recommend it, but I have huge issues with a few things. First off, everyone talks about how there's an amazing story, but honestly there's no story whatsoever. There is nothing but a setting. The setting is incredible; to be sure, and it is revealed beautifully and in a way that makes it feel like a story, but there is absolutely no plot. I felt no motivation to play other than wondering what the end was. The only story to be gleaned is what people theorize after watching the vague ending play out. If you are coming for the story, you will be intrigued the whole time, but leave feeling dissatisfied and sold short.  There are also many sequences with very large distances to cover, frustratingly so given your character's movement speed. This is especially frustrating during one of my favorite parts in the game, the 20 man puzzle, as it's plagued with backtracking vast distances. The artwork isn't good enough to fill the time gap these massive distances create.  The underwater section grew very monotonous and tedious very quickly as well, to the point where I was dreading anytime my feet got a little wet. Luckily it stopped after a while but I was very frustrated with that whole segment and almost stopped playing at it.  That all being said, the universe this takes place in is just fascinating and worth the money just to have it revealed to you. the clever puzzles are an added bonus, and the last-second escape sequences throughout the game are breathtaking and always have you on edge. You always feel both in danger and in awe at the same time. The art is fantastic, and the animations are quite possibly the best I've seen in any game, and perfectly complement the nice and tight controls.  The experience is great and worth your money; only the level design hurts the otherwise outstanding gameplay, and the lack of a plot removes a lot of potential humanity and motivation I desparately wanted to feel for our protagonist. I guess given some of the theories about the game that might be intentional, but during the first playthrough it really just made me less excited for what should be an easy 10/10 game. But again, absolutely worth the money. You should definitely play it.

An atmospheric, breath-taking journey through a world that just isn't quite right. If you want a leveling system or complex, convulted mechanics, go play another f***ing game you cynics. This game is utterly worth it in every way and I invite all of you to enjoy being as harrowingly unsettled as I was.

Okay, let's start with what you may have seen in other reviews.  This game is absolutely incredible. For a game of this type, sometimes pacing can make you walk away and forget the game is in your library. In INSIDE, the pace is utterly perfect. The intensity builds from the beginning and the ambiance is truly inspiring. There are no words, but so much story oozes through its morbid tone. I had more and more burning question as the game went on. It all built to the ending where you arrive and the center of it all - where all of your questions will be answered one by one, silently through observation and interaction with the environment.  BUT THAT DOESN'T HAPPEN!  You reach the end - the game slows to a halt and ♥♥♥♥♥ the bed. It answers absolutely none of your questions and does not even provide clues or things you can interpret how you wish.  I am colossally disappointed in the ending of this game - so much so that if the rest of the game was not LITERALLY perfect, I'd consider this a trainwreck of a game.  Nevertheless, if you are looking for an extremely creative 3 hour ride through a surreal, grim world...check it out.

THIS GAME IS A MASTERPIECE. INSIDE is the creepiest and one of the eeriest games I have ever played, bar none. On a scale of 1-10 for creepiness, I give it a 11! I can almost guarantee you that you won't see the plot twist(s) and ending coming - and the game does it with absolutely zero dialogue. Hours after completing the game, I am still dumbfounded by the ending and the thinking about what it means. It sounds like an impossible balancing act, but the game concludes in a way that doesn't leave you hanging....and it doesn't answer all of your questions either.  It would be a sin to not talk about how good this game looks. Every frame in this game is a painting! Screenshots from this game could go in a museum. While most games tend to exhibit the limitations of its graphics with stuff like jagged lines or overdone lighting, the graphics in INSIDE are....perfect! Everything is just so polished, one has to nitpick to notice something out of place. The game is also very careful with its colour palette. It purposefully maintains only cool colours throughout, and reserves warm colours for only things that are supposed to draw the player's attention to it.  This game also sounds as eerie as it plays. There were times I almost felt claustrophobic because the character's heavy breathing in enclosed spaces sounded so believable. There is no actual soundtrack, only sounds, and you are reminded of everything through sound. From the echo of flipping a metal switch in an empty room to running out of breath underwater, the immersive sonic experience makes you fully believe that you are in the game.  This game has been in development for six years (!) and it shows. It draws you in, keeps you curious, and then it shocks you. And my favourite part is how it pulls it off without going out of its way to make the point. By not using dialogue to tell the story, and restricting the colour palette of the graphics, and not having a soundtrack, this game is a pure masterclass in self-restraint and subtlety.  *tip: don't play this game at night  *tip 2: don't play this with earpieces if you have claustrophobia

The game has an amazing atmosphere. There are few games that really really master it. It feels like a cross between Halflife 2, with it's dystopian-completely-hopeless feel, and Out of This World with it's gameplay. The play is fluid, the character & backgrounds are nuanced and subtle. I haven't finished it yet, but it's sometimes a little humorous, sometimes scary as heck, always moody and gorgeous. It's not particularly difficult, a few sections I've had to replay a number of times to solve the puzzle, but haven't been stuck yet. Although there were a couple that took me a little bit to work out the controls (e.g. press and hold down to turn the crank).  The music & sound is fantastic and fitting. The story is slowly revealed and interesting. The controls are pretty perfect, fluid. The only very very minor thing with controls: I modified before even playing was remapped 'grab' and 'jump' to something a little more normal.  There are some action sequences, where stuff is happening and you need to react reasonably quickly, but those are well separated by running through a whole host of interesting locations, or more leisurely puzzles.  It can be a bit graphic at times, I was pretty surprised the first few times I perished (I've been strangled, drowned, shot, exploded, crushed, mauled to death by animals...).  I can't give this enough thumbs up.
In one word: MASTERPIECE! Absolutely brilliant, i feel sorry that there are very few game on the market with this quality and atmosphere. A piece of ART!

Like Limbo before it, Inside is a dark and immensely well-done puzzle platformer. Every aspect of this game is superb, from the sound, lighting, animation, to the subtle way the camera shifts perspective so this sidescroller really feels set in a 3D world. I took more screenshots in this game than any other in recent memory. Every single shot looks like a well framed photograph; this is how excellent the art direction was.   Inside is a deeply disturbing but astounding and immersive. It will make you hold your breath in moments of tension and shout in moments of panic, all the while glued to your screen. Every time you think it can't get any more creepy or bizarre, it outdoes itself.   Yes, it is a short game. A full play-through is about 3-4 hours. However, finding the secrets, collecting achivements, and exploring things missed in the first run through should add a number of extra hours if you explore organically rather than using guides.  As far as gameplay, the puzzles are clever but never difficult or frustrating, and the challenge is in finding the solution, not having the coordination or finger dexterity to execute it. Plays very well on a controller.  There is really nothing I can say about the actual story/content of the game that wouldn't somehow dampen the experience of a first time player, so I'm going to say nothing but: BUY THIS. PLAY THIS. Definitely my favourite game this year and probably in my top ten list of all time. Opinions on the ending has been very polarised, but personally I liked it.  I seldom buy full priced games nowadays but this is one that is completely worth it.

As someone who felt that Playdead's  Limbo  was overrated, I have to admit that their follow-up  INSIDE  was a bit of a surprise. Whereas the former felt like a floaty, style-over-substance Flash platformer, the latter feels far more mature and refined in its execution.  The puzzle design is at times quite clever and always intuitive. The game never bombards the player with too many moving parts—and there's very little bactracking involved, meaning that moving forward is usually the right solution.  One major criticism to note: often the environments over-indulge in wide, empty areas, which at times feels like deliberate padding in a rather short game.  The demo gives an excellent overview of the final product—if you're not sure if this game is for you, you'll know by the end of the demo.

This is a great game. I'm just over four hours into it, and I feel bad every time the boy dies. And, you will die a lot. It will be brutal. The brutality of this game amazes me.  The general atmosphere of the game reminds me of Half Life 2. This is what the world would look like after Gordon Freeman has rid us of the Combine, yet the broken down technology remains and there are bad people that want to use what is left. There is also a sense of Portal, with the large corporate environments devoid of life. There are zombies, too. Not the type that eat brains; they are your allies/helpers this time around.  I played a bit of Limbo, but it didn't grab me like INSIDE. I can play for 20 - 30 minutes, then I have to stop. The puzzles are challenging, but not overwhelming. Two concerns I had before buying and what I think about them after completing the game:   Too short?   A first play through without the optional puzzles (for the achievements) takes around 6h, so yes, it's a bit short for $20. BUT: considering the insane level of polish and attention to detail (graphics, animations!!, sound, overall atmosphere) and that there is absolutely none of your typical 'filler content' to stretch play time, it is well worth it, even at full price.   Too easy?   Yes, the puzzles are rather easy, but not because they are obvious, bland or trivial (actually, some of them are quite involved), but because there is always only a single mandatory puzzle at any given time and there are no red herrings (objects that look as if they were important but actually they are just a distraction). So, you always know the obstacle at hand and what tools you have to overcome it, which makes it less likely to get stuck. If this is a pro or con depends on preference, but I enjoyed this a lot, because it allows to solve the puzzles by logical thinking rather than frustrating trial and error or looking up solutions on the web. I had some nice eureka moments. Also, this game is a lot about atmosphere, and getting stuck on a puzzle for hours would compromise that.  Overall fantastic game and a must-buy for people who like atmospheric games.

I think this is my first review of a game. I remember paying LIMBO on another account and got so invested in the story, I shed a tear when it ended. This game is no different and in face an even better sequel than I could have hoped for. You need to play this. It's terrifying, beautiful, and clever all at the same time. I recommend this game to anyone. I mean anyone. I don't care if this is your first puzzle/platform experience. This game is truly a work of art.

After playing Limbo and how good that was I never thought INSIDE would top it, boy was I wrong and this might one of my favorite games this year. I'll try to keep this as spoiler free as possible and I'll split this review up into three parts (Presentation, Gameplay, and Verdict)    Presentation  Right from the start this game pulls you in with it's dark and capitivating setting, I love this world and helping that is the excellent sound design and graphics. This game looks stunning especially with all the smoke, rain, fire, and dirt effects that's present in almost every section of the game. The same goes for the sound with the music and sound effects adding to the game as you go seemlessly from one part to another.    Gameplay  At first INSIDE looks like a simple 2D puzzle platformer with a dark setting but it's more than that, each puzzle is wonderfully design and at times they can be a little confusing but thankfully they're not too difficult and don't increase in difficulty as the game goes on which is nice. Both keyboard and gamepad controls are great and not too complicated though for a puzzle platformer that's not too surprising. You will probably die a few times however, and usually it's your own fault which is good.   Verdict  I think this is an absolutely stellar game and in my opinion it's better than Limbo, now for $20 you're probably gonna complete this game in around 3-4 hours which is a little short but thankfully there's some collectibles if you missed them. Sadly that's about it when it comes to replayabilty and if that's not enough you might wanna wait for a price drop. That said if you can get past that then this is easily worth the $20 just for the experience alone and this is definitely a contender for one of my favorite games this year. So what are you waiting for, Stop playing outside and go play INSIDE.

After my my first rage implied review bacause of the feeling I wasted a not quite small amount of money for this game I'm now going give this a second fair review after looking through calm eyes and watching a Let's Play of it until the part to where I have played to myself. Unfortunately that just opened my eyes to even more bad things and I still didn't find anything good.   Most of the time in this game I was totally bored. The puzzle parts that don't directly kill you every time you make something wrong are too easy, there is no real mind challenge. The calmness and the abscence of actual music (only like sounscapes) is causing me like a soporific feeling in these none action areas. The only game that made me more sleepy was Coma: Mortuary, but luckily that came with a price that would be a fair one for Inside too. The only moments that pulled me out of that boredom, unfortunately just with annoyance, were the situations were the game chased me into certain death to tell me that I should have doing something different here just that it is already to late now to change anything about that. Something like that is just a clear indictment for bad gamedesign, as in a platformer you should have at least the theoretical chance to react in time so that can be called 'difficulty level'. And that brings me to my next point, the dying or rather killing animations. They are too realistic, too brutal, too detailed and too lenghty for a platformer, I simply don't want to have to see that again an again. From normally in platformer games I would expect to be able to step back into gamplay asap after a really brief animation and not having to ♥♥♥♥ myself up about having to see that gruesome ♥♥♥♥ again. But no, Playdead has to torture their customers.  Sidenote: These last two were the the only critic points in my first review, even though not so thoroughly formulated.  Everybody talks about impressive graphics and a great story, well the monotonous graphics (yet compared to Limbo or Monochroma) did just add for me to the soporific feeling and I don't see a story at all in this game. Yes  it somewhat reflects our real world/the system we live in/a likely future  , but I don't need a game for telling me about these problems and I certainly don't find that creative.  I got it for 13,49€ and I regretted to have paid that much money in a way I never did before if it comes to video games. And I even regret even more having made the decision (thinking about it for eleven days), after playing it for 1.6 hours and absolutely not liking it, to give Inside another chance instead of asking for a refund because so many people claim to so absolutely love everthing about this game. My impression of it is just like, 'Lets take everything that was bad about Limbo and multiply it for our new game'.

It's Limbo 2.0, basically. More polished, shinier, darker, yet samey and more pretentious than a french art movie. As far as I can tell, it's a story about classism this time, and not about dead boys in purgatory. The style is neat, but the puzzles are barely an obstacle, in this neverending journey to the right, which takes about 3-4 hours to complete. It didn't feel rewarding to complete, and the 'intentionally obscure' angle felt like a cop out in order to make a dark game without explaining anything. Buy it on sale or something.

I've just finished the game and boy am I disappointed. I've paid 22$ for this game, and I've finished it in 4 hours. The gameplay is good and the atmosphere is amazing, but I've got one problem with it.The puzzles are fun (not all of them to be honest, some are tedious just because of the character's walking speed) and the environment is breathtaking. It's a well designed game. Throughout the game, not much is explained and the story is left to your imagination.    My problem with it is the ending. I expected some kind of revelation, or some kind of moment of clarity, but my questions about the story are still unanswered. There's something about becoming a big ball of humans that really got on my nerves. I don't know anything about his past, or why exactly he was in that situation. Why were the people in the 'à la Fallout' underground vault experimenting with human genetics or whatever it was they were experimenting with? Were they humans? Why was there upside-down water? When exactly does this take place? Yes it had good gamefeel, good atmosphere, good everything, really, but I still feel disappointed with this. There's something missing, I feel.   Who knows, there might be DLC or something soon. It's a good game, yes, but I don't think it was worth 22$. I was expecting a bigger game for that kind of money, but whatever. Maybe that's just my inside jew kicking in.

The game's 'arc' goes like this:   opening = fantastic middle = tedious end = unsatisfying  After watching the trailer I was really hyped for Playdead's This War of Mine, which is what the opening is, but then the game starts spinning you around in circles until you reach the end and nothing makes sense. I get the appeal and understand why this game is so unique. Its getting rave reviews everywhere and definitely will go down as a very memorable game. So lets talk pros and cons:  PROS:  1) Great art style and unique animation/graphics 2) Eerie and mind twisting plot/atmosphere 3)... thats it  CONS: 1) The puzzles get old really quick, Most of these puzzles seem so thought out to be randomly laid out in terms of their solution. Eventually, the puzzles get old and I just want to move forward with the story, 2) The story is too open to interpretation and the whole way you are wondering who the boy is, who the bad guys are, why are they hunting you, at some point I just got tired of wondering why things are they way they are and getting NO explanation. Onve you finish it, you're gonna Google the ending explanations and digest whats there. Not gonna spoil it, but it still left me disapoointed.... 3) There is absolutely no closure on the story in any way. And I mean NONE. I know they devs intended this but it just didnt set well with me. And this is coming from someone who WORSHIPPED Journey, which I think has the same thought provoking moments that this game strives to have.  All in all, its a decent game, but no where near the perfection Im reading from all these reviews. It might sit well with you and knowing the type of games I like, I thought it was right up my alley too. But the more I played it, the more I just wanted it to end...  So I'll be the contrarian and say this game is unique and has its moments, but overall isnt a gem.

Alright. Did I enjoy this game? Yes. I enjoyed playing it very much. It was beautiful and suspensful without being outright scary, but it didn't deliever.  And when I say it didn't deliever, I mean I didn't even know when the game was over. There was no indication (aside from the fact that I couldn't move anymore) that I'd reached the end. I only kept playing it because I was expecting something to tie everything together, but it never happened. I was wondering about the world while I played, but nothing was ever answered-- and not in the 'oh, how cool and interpretive!' sort of way, more in the 'the ♥♥♥♥' sort of way. I think the reason everyone is raving about it so much is because of the way it can be interpreted (I had to read three articles to glean a semblance of what was going on, and even then most of it hinged on the secret ending). 'So deep,' the reveiwers said, 'we're the monster all along!!!' << Kidding.   The plot (???) aside, the game was beautiful. I saw people appluading the games soundtrack, which I'm going to argue with; it was very minimal. Was the sound design absolute excellent? Yes. The soundtrack? I can't remember a single memorable tune-- did the game have any music?   Some of the puzzles stumped me, but I enjoyed solving them.   Aboslutely NOT worth $20. Absolutely OVERHYPED. Absolutely UNDERDEVELOPED. Unsatisfying.   If you're looking for a seriously suspensful experience with fantastic atmosphere and a VERY open-ended narrative, this is for you.  When it's on sale, anyway.   I wish I could return it.   And I know people might think I didn't 'get' the ending, but I'm not dumb. I understood the ending, but I feel like it killed the narrative cold.

Short version: INSIDE is like LIMBO, but a bit more complex.  Long version: Inside is a clever short puzzle platformer about a boy in a city and places where science happens.  In all honest: I haven't got the faintest clue what the heck the story was supposed to be about, so I feel I can't give the game a score in the story category, but all other aspects were damn near spot on.  The visuals, while fairly flat and simplistic, are well stylized and serve their purpose well. The 2D/3D gameplay does cause the occasional issue where I failed to judge jumps properly, but this is a very short-term nuisance, since death is not really penalized in this game.   Sound-wise the game is, again, simple but effective. There is no dialogue, the music is minimalist, ambient sounds are very much the same, but in all that simplicity I felt that the sound did it's job very well.  The puzzles, which are the main meat of INSIDE, do pretty much everything they can to get the most out of the simplistic 'stick and two buttons' control scheme. You jump, push, pull, run swim and jump your way through a myriad interesting locations as the game's curious, if somewhat unfathomable, story unravels on the background.  All in all, I felt INDISE was a pleasant experience and I recommend it.   Playtime: 4+ hours (Single playthrough)  Ratings (1-10) Visual: 9 Audio: 8 Story: N/A Gameplay: 9 Overall: 9

INSIDE is a queer, immersive, and beatiful game. It puts you in control of a young boy on the run, evading guards and getting around obstacles - but why? The game doesn't tell you anything about its grim world in text or dialogue, and it's up to the player to make their own interpretation based on what they see. Along the boy's journey you pass through various areas of this strange world - all of them gorgeous. The game is full of suprises up until the very end, and you never feel like it overstays its welcome.  The gameplay itself may not be terribly challenging or, on a base level, new. You run to the right, hide from guards, and solve some puzzles that shouldn't take more than about a minute to figure out. Yet it still sets itself apart with how well done these simple mechanics are done. The animations of the main character feel very organic, and the way the game is set up you never feel like you're doing something you've already done before, nor do the puzzles ever feel out of place.   The game takes around 3-4 hours to complete on your first run through, and aside from some hidden secrets there's no major incentive to replay it. However, the brief time it takes to play it is something you'd be hard pressed to find in any other games out there. If you're looking for a challenging platformer, this isn't the game you want. If you on the other hand want to immerse yourself in a unique experience, I couldn't recommend it enough.

Playdead's debut game, Limbo, sent shockwaves through the indie scene, showing the true might of people who are dedicated to creating video games. With the expectations high like a breakout musician releasing their sophomore album, Inside more than exceeded what anyone could have predicted. Buttery smooth gameplay, satisfying puzzles, and gorgeous sounds are rich within this game, coalescing into an experience that is matched by few. Playing Inside feels like reading a literary classic, something to behold, something you have to put a little more effort into, and something you might have to go through a few times at the least to really suck every last ounce of marrow out of, which to me is yet another reason that makes it great. This is a game that has rejuvinated my love for games, and is not only one of the best games to come out this year, but has made my list for top five games of all time.  Please play this game, it is quite a journey.

INSIDE (much like the game LIMBO) is a dark and sinister platformer that utilizes physics-based puzzles and tells its abstract story through the environment. The basic controls, carefully hand-crafted levels and stylized art style are living proof that a simple game can still be easily as enjoyable as any big-budget title.  You start the game as a young boy that appears to be on the run from militants, who won’t hesitate to ruthlessly end your life if they catch you. The game contains an overall theme of oppression, seemingly inflicted by hidden corporate agenda. Your goal is to somehow find the purpose that drives the sinister machine that holds the lower-class population captive.  The animation of the various characters and how they interact with each other and the world around them is almost flawless. The sound design is even better! It’s startling how effectively the sense of fear and desperation is portrayed from the player character’s body language alone.  During my first play through of INSIDE, I was truly shocked to see some of the many gruesome ways that you could be undone. Some of the puzzles have pretty clear answers, others took a moment of observation in order to identify the intended solution. More than once, I was stumped and unsure of how to overcome certain challenges on the main story path. I expect smarter players would have less difficulty.  Much like LIMBO, there are secrets lightly scattered throughout the game in the form of breakable “lamps”, which offers a small degree of replayability. The achievements associated with them all contain clues in their descriptions to how to find them, and are listed in chronological order of appearance within the game. It’s not too hard to find the general area where they’re located, but actually reaching the lamps requires some careful searching. There is also a hidden “ending”, which is only accessible after unlocking all the achievements, but finding it without a guide is only a couple of notches shy of Hideo Kojima levels of challenging: You don’t have to think like an “Augmented Reality” gamer to find it, but knowing where to go and remaining tirelessly observant is half the battle.  If you liked LIMBO, you’ll like INSIDE. Its brilliant simplicity belies a level of depth that many developers still fail to deliver. You’ll be daunted, surprised and on the edge of your seat from beginning to end, and left with as many questions as you found answers, any of which could further colour the interpretation of the game’s message. It’s an abstract masterpiece and I highly recommend it to all mature audiences (so long as they don’t have a morbid fear of attack dogs).  For Twitch streamers and YouTube gamers, this title is one that absolutely must be played without a walkthrough. For everyone else, buy it and play it for yourselves first! It’s worth the price of admission for an unspoiled, immersive experience.

It's about the journey, not the destination. This game feels like playing a Stephen King novel. If you're a fan of his writing, you understand reading his work is more about the journey than the destination. Like a typical King story, this game keeps you asking questions, but never really answers any of them. Gameplay-wise, I'd give this game a 9/10. It's fun and the puzzles are challenging while not being so difficult they suck the fun out of it. Load times are minimal and checkpoints are sensible. Even though you have very little idea what's going on, why everything is trying to kill you or who you even are, the game design does a great job of making it pretty obvious where to go next. The puzzle objectives are always clear but the game keeps you thinking in different ways. It uses several completely different mechanics that you don't really see coming, but still seem to fit well with the 'theme' of this game, whatever that is.  Story-wise, this game has no real beginning, coherent narrative or cathartic ending. I won't spoil it but I will tell you it just kind of ends. There's no epic boss battle, no race against the clock final dash, no great antagonist reveal. It just kind of ends. There is no intro, and the credits roll on the last scene. There are no cutscenes, nothing to read or listen to (dialog or writing). The 'enemy' NPCs don't seem to have much to do with each other. One really creepy and strange enemy stalks you at several points in the game, then helps you inexplicably. Maybe there is a coherent narrative going on here but I failed to pick up on it. It is interesting and thought-provoking, but no so much that you even really know what questions to ask. So, if you're looking for a game with a clear plot and epic ending, this game is not for you.  If you're into atmosphere and creepy, weird and mysterious games. It's a 2.5D survival horror platformer.  Also worth noting is there are no collectibles, except a few items you may hold temporarily to solve a puzzle. In fact the only thing that you can even check off, other than checkpoints (which you can load to at any time, which is nice if you want to go back) are achievements, of which there are only 14, all of which consist of finding hidden-- devices you deactivate, for unknown reasons. If you get them all, a final one is available and an alternate, equally inexplicable ending can be found. I won't spoil it either but it answers nothing and just restarts the game when you get it.  I do highly recommend this game, even if I am highly critical of it's narrative. Even though the plot isn't coherent, it's still interesting to experience, just don't get your hopes up for an explanation. Just enjoy the journey :D  Also worth noting is the price. I paid $19.99 and the game feels really short. I would expect the price to be lower or the game to be about twice as long.

I definitely recommend this game. I won't spoil anything, because this game needs to be played without any knowledge about what is going on in the story. All I'll say is that   INSIDE   is a perfect example of video games as a narrative medium. The game tells its story through interactions, visuals, and sounds in a way that many other games do not.  The game will last you around three hours, but please understand that this is a game that is about delivering an experience through interaction. There are a lot of reviews on here that the game is 'too easy' or that it's 'too short,' but you have to understand that the developer is not trying to create a lengthy puzzle platformer game with a series of challenges like   Portal   or something. Nor is this a game where 'story' comes first, and gameplay is left at the wayside. Instead, gameplay and story and meshed together in a way that benefits both aspects. Before you buy the game, make sure that you're okay spending $20 on that experience. The developers clearly worked hard on this game, and I believe they deserve that money, but there are plenty of people complaining that they didn't get their money's worth or something to that point. It's a $20, three hour long narrative experience that is worth playing.

THIS. GAME. There's so much stuff that I want to say about it that I don't know where to start. Beautifully crafted and cinematic. Subtle details in the foreground and background create an environment that draws you in from the start and wouldn't let go for the entire 2-3 hour experience.  Gameplay wise it is very similar to LIMBO, environmental platforming and puzzles, it may take several tries to figure out the 'trick' of a particular segment.  The story (if you can call it that) is really the big selling point of this game. You will be flooded with questions about the world and your place in it. I must have went through a dozen different possible explainations and scenarios before the game decided to throw the most bizarre twist. All I can say is, what you're expecting is not going to be what you get.  So if you like analysing and dissecting ambiguous and very thoughtful plots, you'll definitely enjoy this experience.   Overall, a very atmospheric, intense, thought-provoking experience, that will follow you long after the game is done.
Entertaining and haunting at the same time.   If you liked Limbo this is a must play!  I would have liked it to be longer, but isn't it always like that with games like these!? :P

It's a highly polished product which kept me wanted more but priced fairly for its content.  9/10 - I want more, give me more!

Awesome adventure game disguised as a physics platformer. I never liked Limbo that much (need to replay it, mayhaps?), but this game is pretty much flawless. It's about 3 hours long and costs twenty Euros, so there is that, but it's three really enjoyable hours.  One thought that stuck with me, especially during the final hour, was: 'This is only possible in video games.' Video games are often clumsy at narrative, but the way Inside realises its story through audio, visuals and interaction, especially in that last third, kind of blew me away. It also feels like the developers spent a whole lot of time building the insane mirror-world presented in Inside, and then chose to cut like 97% of that world and that storytelling from the actual game. No exposition, no explanation, no dialogue - now if you want to tell a mysterious story, that's exactly the right way to do it. There is nothing quite like it, so go buy it.

Inside  is the next game from the studio that made 2010's  Limbo , and you can definitely tell. The team built off  Limbo  in a few ways: the game again stars a kid in a scary, atmospheric world, and the platforming and puzzle mechanics are similar. Inside is twice as long as is predecessor, and has a little more of a tangible narrative. While the story is not concrete or straightforward, there's more to chew on, with recurring themes and concepts appearing throughout. It's also worth noting that weird games are often rough around the edges, but  Inside  is one of the more polished and smooth-running games I've played this year.  As with  Limbo , I don't think  Inside  is revolutionary, but its style and execution are excellent. Check it out if a strange atmospheric puzzle-platformer sounds like fun.

[Re-review] In hindsight, I realize that I probably shouldn't review things while I'm irritated. That last review was a bit more scathing (and wordy) than I meant it to be. So now, having calmed down a bit and sorted through my thoughts effectively, I'm-a going to try giving this review a second shot.  Inside is a surreal adventure through beautifully rendered and haunting environments. Gameplay is fairly minimal; consisting mostly of running to the right, solve a few puzzles, then keep running to the right. The game's minimalism works both for and against the game. The lack of general clutter and contact with other people lends well to an eerie and unsettling atmosphere. Unfortunately, due to the size of the maps, this means there are long stretches of nothing but your character running against a grey background. Most of the game is tedious like that. The endings can best be described as 'out of left field' for the normal ending and 'pointless waste of time' for the 'secret' ending.  I'll still recommend it, but I'm going to also recommend you wait for a sale. There's just not enough game here to validate a $20 price tag.

First of all,   Inside  has fantastic atmosphere, stellar pacing, a well developed and original (if somewhat hard to decipher) story, and (I'll grudgingly admit) some cooool artsy-fartsy graphics. And on a very simple level, the game is fun. Its fun to look at, satisfying to control, and even pounds your heart in some places. It is  very  similar to  Limbo , to the point where many are calling it a sequel. And  Inside  even uses its puzzle elements in very close, fluid conjunction to the plot, whereas Limbo just tossed in puzzles inbetween (which is one of the things that impressed me most about  Inside ). It definetly counts as a 'good game', and if you are the kind of gamer looking for a good narrative and some cinematic shots, this game is  absolutely  worth the $20. It even has a healthy amount of secret items and slightly different animations/interactions you can get each time you play an area, plus a very satisfying and cool secret ending.  That being said, the gameplay is a bit lacking. Just like  Limbo , it frequently makes use of the same 'trial and death' mechanics, where once you die you automatically realize how to survive the immediate puzzle. But in Limbo, you had to die over and over until you were a master of flipping gravity and avoiding spikes, and sometimes you had to stop and think about the best way to go about a situation. To afford all of the awesome story elements, Inside gave up on any puzzle or gameplay that costs more than half a head scratch. There's never a puzzle that requires shifting your thinking, or asking a friend, and if you get stuck on a puzzle, it's because there was a box you didn't realize you could push, or a something that nobody told you you could fit though. Even one of the only complicated puzzles in the game requires you to break a previous mechanic by hitting it with a platform, in a way that you couldn't have known, and after that it was smooth sailing.  Which is an absolute shame because some of the mechanics in  Inside  are really compelling and original. The type of puzzle I like to call 'pikmin puzzles' is actually really cool, especially the interesting twist on it that the developers pull on a level with a minecart (not to spoil too much). But then you never see it again except in a secret area once. You never see any puzzle elements come back or combine in any meaningful way. And when you go back to play it a second time (because you definetly will want to) you will remember all these puzzles you bumped into before and think, 'that was cool, why didn't that ever come back?'   All in all ,  Inside  is a really great game if you like original, artsy, and meaningful gameplay-driven games; an above average game if you like pretty and satisfying platforming; and a maybe okay game if you are looking for interesting puzzles. Consider before you purchase at full price, but  definetly  worth it at any discount.

INSIDE is better than LIMBO in every way (no spoilers)  The puzzles are better - there's far more variety in puzzle mechanics, which is impressive considering the game is a bit longer, and much less dependence on trial-n-error in order to be difficult. Sure you'll still die a lot but, off the top of my head, I can only think of one puzzle in INSIDE that you'll throw a lot of lives at in order to figure out the proper timing of.   And even when INSIDE does revisit mechanics it'll do so with a new twist that completely changes the mechanic (as opposed to stuff like the brain-slugs which function exactly the same each time the appear in LIMBO)  Overall the game might be a little easier than LIMBO but it's hard for me to judge that because of how much I played LIMBO. Being very familiar with how this dev likes to construct puzzles gave me a leg up I think.   The atmosphere and narrative presentation are better - You know how LIMBO starts out strong with the spider and the guys setting traps but then shifts focus about halfway through to pure puzzles? It's like along the way the game loses something that drew the player in at the start. INSIDE manages to stay strong in that regard not only throughout the entire game but also ramp things up at the end so you know you're in the climax. Much improved over the way LIMBO just sort of suddenly ends.  Even the hidden secrets are better - LIMBO had hidden eggs that, for the most part, were pretty impossible to find and weren't very satisfying to collect. INSIDE gives players a visual clue (once they know what to look for) that a secret area is nearby and once they get in there are often presented with unique puzzles that aren't found in the main game. Collecting the secrets also leads up to an alternate ending that provides a bit of context for those trying to unravel the surreal story. It's actually pretty fun finding everything and makes it worth replaying the game in order to get 100%.  Overall I can't say you'll like INSIDE if you didn't enjoy LIMBO but it does improve on the formula in every way, so fans of the first game should play this follow-up sooner rather than later. It's an amazing experience and I can't wait to see what the studio does next.
