As a big fan of LIMBO I was excited to hear that Playdead was finally releasing another project. Upon seeing the trailer for INSIDE I was on board and quickly purchased the game. Now I must say, LIMBO is one of my favorite games of all time and quite excellently does what so many minimalist indie art games try to do. Frankly, I was concerned that INSIDE would be more or less aping off the success LIMBO had and would be a rather lazy formulaic 'sequel'. But it isn't. This game takes the style pioneered in LIMBO and delves deep into improving it. From the obviously massive amounts of care and effort put into the graphics and animations to finding new ways to explore the sidescrolling gameplay, this game borders on perfect.   If you are on the fence about buying this game at all I strongly recommend buying it, the experience is worth your money and Playdead has certainly earned it. If dollars seems high for this sort of thing (which is understandable) keep and eye for it to be on sale and get it as soon as you can. You will not regret it.

I spent about 70% of my time with this game wondering what in God's name everyone else was gushing about. Yes, right from the opening it's clear that INSIDE has excellent art design and incredible animation. Visually the game is a work of art. The sound design is understated, and effectively supports the games thick atmosphere. The gameplay however, left me confused as to why this was made as a game, and not an animated film. The needlessly basic platforming and overly simplistic puzzle design often felt like padding. These elements were ultimately detracting from, rather than enhancing my experience. Playing this game wasn't enjoyable, satisfying, or challenging.   Then came the closing stretch which turned everything around. This gave me something I had never experienced from this medium and will likely sit comfortably among my favourite moments in gaming. To elaborate any further would only spoil things, so I'll just say this final chapter made any boredom leading up to it completely worth it.  INSIDE is worth experiencing. While I found that for the majority of its very brief runtime the gameplay was banal and completely unsatisfying, the atmosphere, animations, visuals, and sound design are top notch throughout. And wow, what a climax...

You don't see games like these so often these days. This little game is a masterpiece. If you've played Limbo before, then the concept will be very familiar. You start your journey as a little boy in an unknown place. Except it is SO much better than Limbo. It takes what was good from that game and makes it better. It succeeds in making you feel hopeful yet hopeless. It slowly creeps you out more and more, all the way to the end, when it becomes one of the creepiest things I've played. And you somehow feel pitty during certain bits but at the same time are scared of that which causes you that pitty. It's strange, but it's fantastic. The ambience created is amazing.   I was left when playing Limbo with a feeling of not understanding at all what was going on or the world I was in. I didn't like that about Limbo. Inside gives you more clues as to where you are, but lets you use your imagination.  Can I also point out the attention to detail. Every move you make, every jump, every step is smoothe and visually charming. I also love the fact that you can hear the protagonist breathing, which draws you into the story even more.  Just a little warning: if you can't wait to buy this game because you adore puzzles such as the ones in Limbo, don't get your hopes up. Limbo was challenging. This game is less so. I'm not a smart person and found the puzzles to be very simple, I didn't have to think too much. At the same time, though, that's what makes the game flow. I myself don't like getting stuck. But don't mind me, maybe I'm just having a good day. I should point out though, as much as I found the puzzles to be simple, I also found them to be extremely creative.   It's worth every cent, even if it is a short game.  Trust me. Just buy it. Do it. Right now.

Every once in awhile comes a new work that defines its own medium. This time it is Inside.  Pros:  Playdead treated their games with care, to a certain point where some would say they are overly meticulous. Yes there are moments where those care take time, like the 6 years development of both Limbo and Inside, I argue that everything was worth it. From the moment the boy in red sweater slid down the boulders as we start the game, every movement of that character was calculated and prepared to make it seems natural. Every step I take took weight. Every jump is a gasp for air, a tiny leap of faith, and every landing is heavier, rough and tough. The way the boy moves through the woods, the concrete, the stones, or stumbling and gaining back posture through puddles makes me experience the texture and the density of the atmosphere rarely felt through any other games or film or novels. Once a restricted medium, games elevates itself through titles like Inside to let the us touch and feel its story and its grimness and its heavy toll it takes each time our character dies meaninglessly and brutally. I am the aesthetic type, and I look mainly for such in games I play. How the wind makes the trees and the leaves rumble, how air feels heavy when we have to enter water again knowing what’s waiting below, how our character stops and exhaust after escaping the flooded elevator. And in this category, Inside deserves it. Everything was done well, and everything was done beyond expected.   Story wise, I would say that Limbo had a clearer answer to all of its mysteries. Inside has too many questions need answering, a bit too many to the point that some claims it is meaningless, lazy or just trying to be cool or ambitious. I like going straight to fandom sites and forum reading discussions between players expecting to know more, or sitting through a bus ride wondering meanings and ideas suggested by the game. In this sense, I enjoyed the jam-packed ideas and subplots Inside poses.   Cons:  Puzzles mechanics are less challenging than those from Limbo, and unlike Limbo where puzzles were ways to introduce you to the mechanic of the game universe itself, Inside’s puzzle are a bit similar to each other at one point or another. This bring up the game pace quite a bit and certainly helps new gamers, especially ones that I introduced this game to.  For movie-like experience or an art-house short game, Inside is quite terrific and beautiful. It is haunting, daring, and while a bit slippery some parts, held up solid and well-presented as one of the most stunning game of all time.

Great art style, some of the best lighting and underwater effects I've seen in a game, excellent puzzle design, and great controls make this one solid gameplay experience, albeit a really messed up one. Limbo was enjoyable but this takes it to a new level. Playdead did an incredible job.

In some way oddly eerie, and intriguing. A piece of art; a game that remains with you once it’s all over. Whether it be the original ending or the alternate, INSIDE creates a strange atmosphere that keeps enticing you to replay and ultimately figure out WHAT THE F*** you’ve just played. Yet, in those few moments during your second or third go – is where you’ll discover INSIDE’s true nature and your interpretation of its beautiful story.  A Highly Recommended game.

Great art style, some of the best lighting and underwater effects I've seen in a game, excellent puzzle design, and great controls make this one solid gameplay experience, albeit a really messed up one. Limbo was enjoyable but this takes it to a new level. Playdead did an incredible job.
Hearing a game through the skull of a real dead person is a first for me; mindblowing when played through a premium audio system. Perfectly paced little gem of a game. Highly recomended.
INSIDE is a hauntingly beautiful and intelligent puzzle platformer.  The story is super satisfying and my only criticism is that there isn't more!  I can see myself revisiting INSIDE over and over.

I'm not a huge fan of stories that lack a conclusion (as of now) or make it seem like there is no correct interpretation.  That being said, the atmosphere and themes of this game are so extremely impressive, that it is still under my top 10 best games ever.
Having played this one through with friends watching, it was a fantastic couch controller game. The environment and art style was truely capitavating.

In this game you play as a young boy lost in a dystopian facility. The game is marked by an eerie atmosphere and tense moments. The controls are easy to use and intuitive, allowing you to guide the boy through puzzles and obstacles. Without a single spoken or written word, the story progesses as you make your way through the facility. The true nature of the facility is slowly revealed as you progress, keeping the player in suspense and adding to the mystique before ending in a way that you will never see coming. I highly recommend this game.  Pros: + Fantastic atmosphere + Dystopian setting + Great visuals + Intuitive controls + Puzzles + Tense moments + Music + Checkpoint system + Hidden areas  Cons: - None really
Cant believe the amazing flow of the game that make us interpret the story by ourself. You guys did very well.
Amazing platform game , worth the money totally.

As many other reviewers have said, it's a pretty short experience, but one that is a great improvement from LIMBO (which I enjoyed as well). The atmosphere is well-drawn, and the plot is fairly engaging though the lack of dialogue and narration leaves much to your imagination. The control scheme was nice. The only negative I can really think of is that there wasn't as much of an emphasis on puzzles this time around. LIMBO had a few that took me at least half an hour to work out. Part of the reason INSIDE seems so short in comparison is that you move forward at a pretty brisk pace. The ending sequence is quite memorable. Not sure I'd recommend at full price, but at any discount it's a good deal.

The creators at playdead must have a sense of what they want in a game, and what they want is for you to figure out the story yourself. Inside is the follow up success of Limbo, both games are fairly similar, however they're locations are wildly different. You play as an unnamed boy (limbo), who's trying to survive the harsh environments (limbo), where you will die in multiple cringeworthy ways (limbo), and will end in such a way that it will have you question your very existence in the shower. I will say the puzzles in this game are a delight and not a test on ones nerves, and the last 20 minutes of this game are incredible. Well done Playdead, well done.
Interesting puzzle game with nice artwork and a strange storyline. It's easy but enjoyable.

INSIDE takes what made LIMBO so good and ramps up nearly every aspect of it. The world strikes a perfect balance between being ambiguous enough to leave you to interpret the game as you wish, but concrete enough to get across the point that the developers wanted to. Its extremely dark and atmospheric, but more importantly the world is just fascinating. Every shocking or jaw dropping moment gives you a reason to continue on through the game to find more about the world.  In terms of gameplay, the game is very tightly scripted, meaning there's pretty much only one way to do anything, one way to solve any puzzle or get from point A to point B. This made the puzzles a bit easy, in my opinion. If you were capable of interacting with an object in the world you immediately knew that object would be used in your current puzzle. I didn't really get stumped a whole bunch, as the scale of the puzzles seemed a bit small (most only have 2-3 things you can interact with at a time), and as a result there wasn't as strong of a feeling of accomplishment when solving most of the puzzles.   However, the heavily-scripted aspect of the gameplay allowed the developers to have a tighter control of the player, and seemlessly integrate the gameplay with the world to immerse the player. You don't really have to worry about making a wrong move and ruining the immersion as the game waits for you to correct yourself. This allows many great moments where you are essentially acting out a climactic moment most games would have to deliver in a cutscene. In INSIDE, you are in control during these moments and feel much more tension during these moments then you would in a simple cutscene.  All in all, INSIDE is another game in a string of 'games as art'. It's biggest accomplishments and innovations come through its experience, atmosphere, and artistic direction, as opposed to gameplay (which is solid but nothing to write home about). If you're looking for the atmosphere and experience, INSIDE will blow you away, but if you're looking for a really brilliant puzzle game there are better options on Steam. Personally I really enjoyed my time with INSIDE.  8.6/10
I enjoyed this more than any other game in 2016. It is a fantastic sureal adventure of an isolated child in a brutally, hostile world. Excellent story-telling and beautifully presented. 10/10.

An absolutely brilliant game. I would highly recommend it to anyone interested in a graphically stunning, side-scrolling, visual story-telling experience.  I was completely engrossed in the story as it unfolded without a line of dialogue, leaving me with many questions and many juicy hints to go back to in the game to form my own theory as to the setting.  The graphics are gorgeous. A darker, moody palette as you can see in the screenshots, with beautiful animations and setpieces. It does a good job of giving you a sense of scale.  The sound design contributes a lot to the atmosphere of the game, and it is top notch.  I still think about this game even though I beat it a few weeks ago. It's no spoiler to say things get quite weird -- and I love it.  This is one of my favorite games of all time.
Play this game.
Absolutely perfect, as was Limbo. But the polish and stylized detail is on a whole new level!!
ending is still simple than maths  10/10 will play inside, inside again.
This game was able to take the essence of Limbo to an unique level!

Please do yourself and the artistic masterminds behind this game a favor by buying this game. Before I even start this review I need to say after just finishing it (it is short yes) this is one of the best gaming experiences I have ever had. A simply perfect game.   That being said it may not be for everyone.  If you are someone that does not like story based or atmospheric games, and prefer just fps's and story shallow games, you might not like this. If you want to try something new though, this is the game I would tell you to play.  This game suprised me in so many ways, and after playing Limbo 4 or 5 times when it was released, I was convinced Playdead could not outdo themselves when they announced a new project. 6 years (and a few months tardy) later and we have Inside, a masterpiece in so many ways. This game will surprise and disgust and shock you, and you'll love it and hate it for it (not to mention one of the coolest easter eggs ever).  Seriously. Stop reading this and buy the game.              (At least try the demo man, then you'll know why you need to buy it.)

An unbelievably dark and gripping tale. So many small phenomena in the game entranced me as I played. Don't read too much into the game as you need to experience it for yourself. The puzzles were quite challenging, but certainly solvable. I highly recommend it!

The puzzles were very challenging despite having very simple solutions. You will always be able to figure them out on your own with time. The atmopshere this game creates is incredible. Beautiful visuals and sounds. Best played in a dark room with earbuds in.

I really enjoyed this game as I did with LIMBO. The whole atmosphere, little puzzles to solve is very relaxing. The game ran flawlessly, no bugs, no lag, it just worked like it should. My single complaint is the ending, I thought it was anti-climatic and was totally surprised to see the credits roll at that point.
You really should experience this game just to see how incredibly well a story and its characters could be delivered entirely through the interaction and striking presentation.
